Yes, there were other actions Ban Ki-moon could have taken to better address human rights violations in conflict zones.

Firstly, Ban Ki-moon could have spoken out more forcefully against human rights abuses perpetrated by all parties to the conflict, including those committed by countries with strong ties and influence in the UN. For instance, in the case of Syria, Ban Ki-moon could have used his position to more strongly condemn Russia for its role in supporting the Syrian government's brutal crackdown on dissent.

Secondly, Ban Ki-moon could have done more to strengthen the UN's human rights mechanisms and make them more effective in responding to human rights abuses in conflict zones. He could have pushed for more resources to support the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights and its work in monitoring human rights abuses and advocating for international justice.

Thirdly, Ban Ki-moon could have advocated for and implemented more preventative measures to address the root causes of conflict and human rights abuses, such as poverty, inequality, and structural injustices. He could have worked more closely with civil society organizations and human rights defenders in conflict zones to promote human rights and democratic values and included them in the UN's decision-making processes.

Finally, Ban Ki-moon could have been more transparent and accountable in addressing allegations of human rights abuses committed by UN personnel, including peacekeepers, and taken swift and decisive action to hold perpetrators accountable.

Overall, while Ban Ki-moon's approach was somewhat effective, there were other actions he could have taken to better address human rights violations in conflict zones.
